abstract.p: Letter from Julie M Ford scoffs at East Side residents angry about Con Ed shutting off some power (June 27 article); says energy cannot be monopolized by wealthy, especially when it is at expense of so many others

block.p: Re ''Con Ed Shuts Off Some Power on East Side'' (news article, June 27):
Re ''Con Ed Shuts Off Some Power on East Side'' (news article, June 27):

I applaud Con Ed. I lived on the Upper East Side several years ago, and my first summer there I was struck by an eerie phenomenon: a steady, low-pitched roar that reverberated throughout the neighborhood. It was the sound of thousands upon thousands of air-conditioners constantly running. As I walked the corridor of high-rise buildings, the air throbbed.

It is time we recognized that energy use is not an entitlement; it is a resource of the community, to be husbanded for the whole community. The ability to afford high levels of energy consumption, to leave the air-conditioner on when no one is home so as to return to a cool apartment, should not be equated with the right to do so.
Energy cannot be monopolized by the wealthy, especially when it is at the expense of so many others.
JULIE M. FORD New York, June 27, 2000
The writer is an assistant professor of sociology, Long Island University.
